State Key Joint Laboratory of Environment Simulation and Pollution Control Research Center for Eco-Environmental Sciences Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100085 China Graphical abstract Methanol steam reforming (MSR) is essential for in-situ hydrogen production, providing a clean fuel alternative for sustainable energy applications. Copper catalysts are widely applied in MSR, yet the nature of active sites and reaction pathway involved remain some debates. Herein, we reveal the crucial role of water activation and dynamic active sites on Cu/Al2O3 catalysts during the MSR reaction. Specifically, methanol was preferentially adsorbed on Al2O3 and underwent stepwise dehydrogenation to formaldehyde, while water was activated on metallic Cu, oxidizing Cu0 to form Cu+-OH species, accompanied by hydrogen migration to another Cu0 site. The Cu+-OH species further reacted with formaldehyde to generate highly reactive formate, whose dehydrogenation produced CO2. Concurrently, the Cu+ was reduced back to the Cu0 state, and H2 was continuously produced by dehydrogenation. Compared to the facile oxidation of Cu0 by water, the slow reduction of Cu+ induced by the dehydrogenation of formate predominated the overall reaction rate at low temperatures. These findings provide new insights into a dynamic Cu0/+-Cu0 site mechanism on copper catalysts in methanol steam reforming, beneficial for the design of efficient MSR catalysts. Keywords Methanol steam reforming Copper catalysts Water activation Dynamic active sites Operando DRIFTS-MS In-situ UV–Vis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen, as a clean fuel alternative with high energy density and zero-carbon emissions, is essential for achieving carbon neutrality, while the challenges of safe storage and transportation hinder its widespread adoption [1]. Methanol Steam Reforming (MSR) stands as a promising solution for in-situ hydrogen production, distinguished by its advantageous features, including low-temperature operation and high hydrogen yield [2,3]. Among MSR catalysts, Cu/Al2O3 catalysts are known for their high catalytic activity and selectivity, while ZnO is often introduced to further enhance the activity and stability of the catalyst, leading to the application of commercial Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts [4,5]. Extensive investigations have been conducted to unravel the mechanistic intricacies and structure–activity relationships of these copper catalysts, encompassing the elucidation of the MSR mechanism by identifying pivotal intermediates and the recognition of active sites on copper catalysts by investigating the correlation between the physical and chemical states of copper and the catalytic activity in methanol steam reforming [3,6,7]. The reaction pathway of MSR on copper catalysts has been widely studied, yet the exact mechanism remains debated. One proposed pathway involved methyl formate as a key intermediate, where two methanol molecules were first dehydrogenated to form methyl formate, which was then hydrolyzed into formate, eventually decomposing to carbon dioxide and hydrogen [8,9]. However, other groups have proposed the pathway involving formaldehyde and formate, with methanol initially dehydrogenating to formaldehyde, followed by its reaction with water to form formate, which subsequently decomposed to carbon dioxide and hydrogen [10,11]. Despite the rough acknowledgement of these intermediates in MSR, the specific reaction sites and the conversion process of intermediates remain unclear. Some studies suggested that the activation of methanol and the subsequent conversion of intermediates occurred on metallic Cu nanoparticles [12,13], while others pointed out that the metal-support interface plays an important role in the conversion of intermediates [14–16]. As for water, which plays an important role in promoting the generation and conversion of intermediates, its activation sites and reaction pathway have been rarely studied. These ambiguities have hindered the understanding of the mechanism and active sites. While many researchers attempted to identify the primary active sites on copper catalysts through mechanistic studies, there was less solid experimental evidence to explain the actual active sites due to the complex physical structure and the redox state of Cu species. Some reports suggested that small Cu nanoparticles could activate methanol at low temperatures [12,17], while others argued that large Cu nanoparticles could avoid adverse support effects to increase the CO2 selectivity [15]. Furthermore, some researchers observed a strong linear correlation between the TOF values and the Cu+/Cu0 ratio, so they proposed that Cu+ species may be active sites [10,13], while other studies argued that Cu0 species were the active sites because both the dehydrogenation of intermediates and H2 formation occurring on the same Cu0 site markedly boosted hydrogen production, with the presence of Cu+ species being adverse to MSR [12]. The contradictions in these studies likely stemmed from the dynamic nature of Cu species during methanol reforming. While numerous studies have investigated the influence of the initial redox state of Cu on methanol steam reforming reactivity and selectivity [10,18,19], few studies have probed the dynamics of Cu species under reaction conditions, which has impeded the recognition of the actual active sites on copper catalysts. In summary, despite the widespread application of commercial Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts in MSR, the active sites and reaction mechanism of copper catalysts remain unclear. To elucidate these aspects, present work focuses on Cu/Al2O3 catalysts, with an emphasis on investigating the changes in Cu species and their role in the methanol steam reforming reaction. Herein, we prepared a series of Cu/Al2O3 catalysts with varying numbers of active Cu sites and then applied them in the methanol reforming reaction. Afterward, the concentrations of surface Cu species on Cu/Al2O3 catalysts were quantitatively calculated and then correlated to the H2 production rate in methanol reforming. Subsequently, the reactive intermediates and the dynamics of active sites in methanol reforming on Cu/Al2O3 catalysts were further investigated using in situ Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy coupled with Mass Spectrometry (in situ DRIFTS-MS), in situ Raman spectroscopy, and in situ Diffuse Reflectance Ultraviolet–Visible spectroscopy (in situ DR-UV–vis). Based on these experiments, we established a correlation between the hydrogen production rate and the quantity of surface Cu species, identified highly reactive intermediates, and investigated the dynamics of Cu species. This work elucidated the reaction mechanism and the dynamics of the active sites during methanol steam reforming on Cu/Al2O3, offering important insight for the design of high-efficiency catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation Cu/Al2O3 catalysts with 0.25 to 10 wt% copper loadings were prepared by an impregnation method. Initially, the required amount of nano-Al2O3 (Sigma-Aldrich) was added to deionized water and stirred to form a suspension. A specified amount of copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, >99 %, Sigma-Aldrich) was dissolved in deionized water and then added to the above suspension with stirring. This solution was subsequently stirred at 353 K to evaporate the excess water, and the samples were dried in an oven at 383 K for 12 h. These samples were then calcined in a muffle furnace at 623 K for 4 h to obtain the Cu x -Al-oxidized samples (x denotes copper loadings). These samples were further reduced in a mixed gas (5 % H2/N2, 100 mL min−1) at 573 K for 1 h to obtain the final catalysts and denoted as Cu x -Al. 2.2 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was carried out on a D8-ADVANCE (Bruker) diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm) at 40 kV and 40 mA. The specific surface area and pore characterization of the catalysts were obtained using a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 analyzer. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) measurement was obtained using an OPTIMA 8300 instrument to determine the exact Cu loadings. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) was performed on a JEOL JEM-ARM 200F microscope with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Diffuse Reflectance Ultraviolet–Visible spectroscopy (DR-UV–vis) analysis was performed on a UV–vis spectrophotometer (LAMBDA 650, PerkinElmer). The spectra were recorded at a resolution of 1 nm, with BaSO4 used as the reference. Raman spectra were obtained using a Renishaw inVia Raman microscope system with a 532 nm-excitation laser. Baseline correction was implemented to mitigate background interference. The H2-TPR experiments were conducted on a chemisorption analyzer (Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 II) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). In a typical measurement, 25 mg of sample was pretreated in 10 % O2/He at 573 K for 30 min and then cooled down to 323 K. Subsequently, the sample was heated to 623 K at a rate of 10 K/min in 10 % H2/Ar. The dispersion of Cu was tested by N2O titration experiments on the same Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 II apparatus. First, 25 mg of a Cu x -Al-oxidized sample was pretreated in 10 % O2/He at 573 K for 30 min. Then the sample was reduced by 10 % H2/Ar with the temperature raised from 323 K to 623 K at a rate of 10 K/min and held at 623 K for 1 h. The amount of H2 consumed (X) was calculated. Then, the sample was cooled down to 323 K in Ar and exposed to 5 % N2O/Ar for 30 min to oxidize the surface Cu0 to Cu2O. Subsequently, the sample was purged with Ar for 30 min to remove the residual N2O. Finally, the sample was heated to 623 K at a rate of 10 K/min in 10 % H2/Ar. The amount of H2 consumed (Y) was calculated. The dispersion of copper (D Cu), the average volume–surface diameter of copper (d Cu) and the concentration of surface Cu species (C Cu) were calculated as follows [20]: (1) D Cu (%) = 2 Y X × 100% (2) d Cu (nm) = 0.5 X Y (3) C Cu (mol/g) = Wt Cu M Cu × D Cu where C Cu is the concentration of surface Cu sites, Wt Cu is the Cu loading of catalysts and MCu is the relative atomic mass of copper (63.46 g/mol). The XAFS spectra at the Cu K-edge were recorded at the BL11B beamline of Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF). The beam current of the storage ring was 200 mA in a top-up mode. The incident photons were monochromatized by a Si(111) double-crystal monochromator. For energy calibration, a copper foil was employed, establishing a reference at E0 = 8979 eV. The reference spectra were measured in transmission mode, with the ionization chambers filled with N2. EXAFS data were processed using the Athena and Artemis software suites [21]. 2.3 Catalytic tests The catalytic tests of methanol steam reforming were conducted in a fixed-bed reactor (interior diameter: 4 mm) [22]. Before the tests, a 100 mg oxidized sample was placed into the reactor and reduced in H2/N2 at 573 K for 60 min. A mixture of methanol and water with a molar ratio of 1.5 was fed into the reactor by an injection pump at a rate of 8.0 μL min−1.The reactants, mixed with N2 (120 mL min−1), were evaporated at 413 K before entering the reactor. The reactants and reaction products were analyzed by an online gas chromatograph (Agilent, GC 8890) equipped with both FID and TCD detectors. The methanol conversion, CO selectivity, H2 production rate, H2 selectivity and the turnover frequency (TOF) were calculated as follows equations. During the TOF test, methanol conversion was kept below 10 % (25 mg of catalyst mixed with 75 mg of silica). (4) Methanol conversion X MeOH (%) = F CO, out + F CO 2 , out + F CH 4 , out F CH 3 OH, in × 100% (5) H 2 production rate (mol g -1 s -1 ) = F H 2 M cat (6) H 2 selectivity (%) = F H 2 3 × ( F CH 3 OH, in × X MeOH ) × 100% (7) CO selectivity (%) = F CO, out F CO, out + F CO 2 , out + F CH 4 , out × 100% (8) TOF ( h -1 ) = F H 2 D Cu × Wt Cu / M Cu where F CH 3 OH, in is the molar flow rate of CH3OH at the reactor inlet. The F CO, out , F CO 2 , out , F CH 4 , out and F H 2 represent the molar flow rates of CO, CO2, CH4 and H2 at the outlet of the reactor, respectively. Notably, H2 selectivity is defined as the ratio of actual amount of H2 produced to theoretical amount of H2 produced, where each molecule of methanol stoichiometrically generates three moles of H2 (CH3OH + H2O = 3H2 + CO2). M cat is the mass of catalyst, D Cu is the dispersion of Cu, Wt Cu is the Cu loading of catalysts and MCu is the relative atomic mass of copper (63.46 g/mol). 2.4 In situ spectroscopic study In situ DRIFTS of CO adsorption were performed by FTIR spectroscopy (Nicolet iS 50) [23,24]. Before the measurements, a 50 mg oxidized sample was placed into a Harrick Scientific cell and reduced in H2/N2 at 573 K for 60 min. After reduction, the sample was cooled to 303 K in a purge of argon flow and exposed to 1 % CO/Ar for 30 min. After the saturation adsorption of CO, the sample was purged in Ar for 30 min to remove weakly adsorbed CO, and the spectrum of CO adsorption was further collected. In situ DRIFTS-MS experiments were performed by FTIR spectroscopy (Nicolet iS 50) and online MS (InProcess Instruments, GAM 200) [25,26]. The spectra were collected with an accumulation of 100 scans at 4 cm−1 resolution, and the gaseous products (H2 and CO2) were detected by online MS. Before the measurements, a 50 mg oxidized sample was placed into a Harrick Scientific cell and reduced in H2/N2 at 573 K for 60 min. The background spectrum was recorded at the corresponding reaction temperature. During the TPSR experiment for the MSR reaction, the sample was ramped up from 50 to 573 K at a rate of 5 K/min in a flow of 500 ppm CH3OH and 750 ppm H2O in N2 balance, with the spectra collected every minute. During step-response experiments, the sample was sequentially exposed to 500 ppm CH3OH/N2 for 30 min, then N2 for 30 min, and finally 750 ppm H2O/N2 for 30 min at 523 K, with the spectra continuously recorded at reaction temperature. During H2O or D2O adsorption experiments, the sample was exposed to 750 ppm H2O/N2 or D2O/N2 at 473 K for 10 min, and the spectra were then collected. In situ Raman spectroscopy was acquired on a Renishaw inVia Raman microscope system equipped with an in-situ cell, using a 532 nm-excitation laser at 2 cm−1 resolution [27,28]. Baseline correction was implemented to mitigate background interference. During water activation experiments, the sample was exposed to 750 ppm H2O/N2 at different temperatures for 10 min, and the spectra were then collected. In situ DR-UV–vis experiments were conducted on the above UV–vis spectrophotometer equipped with a Harrick Scientific cell [22,29]. The spectra were recorded from 800 to 400 nm at a rate of 1 nm/s with 5 nm resolution. It should be noted that the disparities between the ex-situ DR-UV–vis spectra and the in-situ DR-UV–vis spectra can be attributed to the distinct experimental modes employed. During experiments, the oxidized Cu5-Al sample was first exposed to N2 for 30 min and subsequently to H2/N2 for 60 min at 573 K to collect reference spectra, followed by subsequent exposure to various gas conditions (750 ppm H2O in N2 balance, 500 ppm CH3OH in N2 balance, and 500 ppm CH3OH and 750 ppm H2O in N2 balance, respectively) at different temperatures for 60 min, and the spectrum was then collected. During step-response experiments, the oxidized sample was pretreated in H2/N2 at 573 K for 60 min and then successively exposed to 750 ppm H2O/N2, 500 ppm CH3OH/N2, 750 ppm H2O/N2, and 500 ppm CH3OH/N2 for 1 h each. The dynamics of Cu species data were obtained by continuously measuring the absorbance at 560 nm with 1 point/s time resolution. 2.5 DFT calculations All density functional theory calculations were performed by the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [30]. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [31] functional was employed to treat the exchange–correlation interactions. The plane-wave basis set with a kinetic energy cutoff of 400 eV, the energy convergence criterion of 10–4 eV, the force convergence criterion of 0.02 eV Å−1 were employed for structure relaxation. A sufficiently large vacuum gap (>12 Å) was employed to prevent the interaction between neighboring periodic structures·H2O was calculated in boxes of 20 Å×20 Å×20 Å with the gamma point only. The Cu(111) model was constructed using five-layer slabs with (2 × 2) surface unit cells. The Cu1/Al2O3 was modeled with a single Cu atom supported by a five-layer Al2O3(110) with (2 × 2) surface. In the optimization process, the bottom three layers were fixed while the remaining layers were relaxed. The Bader charge analysis employed a grid-based weighting method, where the fraction of space neighboring each grid point that transfers to its neighbors was utilized as a weight for discrete integration of functions across the Bader volume. 3 Results and discussion A series of Cu/Al2O3 catalysts with various copper loadings (0.25–10 wt%), denoted as Cu x -Al (x wt%), were synthesized using an impregnation method. The exact Cu loadings were determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) (Table S1). During methanol steam reforming (Figs. 1 a and S1), Al2O3 demonstrated complete inactivity in H2 production and methanol conversion, while impregnation with a tiny amount of Cu barely improved the catalytic performance of Cu0.25-Al. However, the Cu2.5-Al catalyst exhibited remarkably increased activity in this reaction, achieving a H2 production rate of 35.7 μmol g−1 s−1 at 513 K. Notably, the Cu5-Al catalyst exhibited the best catalytic performance in methanol reforming for H2 production, achieving nearly complete methanol conversion and a H2 production rate of 52.0 μmol g−1 s−1 at the same temperature, which demonstrated to be an efficient MSR catalysts compared to other reported copper-based catalysts (Table S2). However, further increasing the Cu content induced a gradual decrease in the H2 production rate on Cu7.5-Al (42.4 μmol g−1 s−1) and Cu10-Al (9.1 μmol g−1 s−1). In addition, the H2 selectivity on Cu5-Al was close to 100 %, accompanied with a low CO selectivity (<1.3 %) over the whole reaction temperature range (Figs. S2 and S3). To ensure a more accurate comparison of intrinsic activity, the methanol conversion was maintained below 10 % at 473 K by adjusting the WHSV, allowing for the determination of the H2 production rate and turnover frequency (TOF) values. As shown in Fig. 1b, the H2 production rate on these Cu catalysts exhibited a volcano-shaped trend, where the H2 production gradually increased from 9.0 μmol g−1 s−1 (Cu2.5-Al) to 19.1 μmol g−1 s−1 (Cu5-Al), followed by a gradual decrease to 11.1 μmol g−1 s−1 (Cu7.5-Al) and 6.9 μmol g−1 s−1 (Cu10-Al). In contrast, the TOF values exhibited minor variations with the increase in Cu content, in the sequence of 216.5 h−1 (Cu2.5-Al), 228.9 h−1 (Cu5-Al), 221.4 h−1 (Cu7.5-Al) and 212.1 h−1 (Cu10-Al). These results indicate that the differences in catalytic activity among the samples were not due to variations in intrinsic activity but were instead linked to differences in the number of active sites. Generally, the catalytic activity of Cu/Al2O3 catalysts in methanol reforming for H2 production is positively correlated with the number of active sites on these samples. Thus, the volcano-shaped trend of the H2 production rate suggested that the concentration of active Cu sites does not monotonically increase with Cu loading. To ascertain the active Cu sites, a range of techniques were employed to assess the physical and chemical state of Cu species on the Cu/Al2O3 catalysts. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis (Figs. S4 and S5) revealed the presence of the γ-Al2O3 phase in all samples. In oxidized samples, the CuO phase was solely detected in the Cu7.5-Al-oxidized and Cu10-Al-oxidized samples. Similarly, in reduced samples, the metallic Cu phase was observed exclusively in the Cu7.5-Al and Cu10-Al samples. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) indicated the presence of highly dispersed Cu atoms on Cu0.25-Al, whereas Cu nanoparticles with progressively increasing sizes were observed on Cu2.5-Al (2.45 nm), Cu5-Al (2.62 nm), Cu7.5-Al (5.29 nm), and Cu10-Al (14.81 nm) (Figs. 2 a, b and S6–S9). Additionally, the similar specific surface areas of Cu5-Al (185.1 m2/g) and Al2O3 (201.0 m2/g) indicated that the specific surface area was not the primary factor in enhancing catalytic performance (Table S1). In situ CO-DRIFTS was conducted with CO as the probe molecule to investigate the state of surface Cu species. As shown in Fig. 2c, only one band at 2114 cm−1, assigned to Cuδ+ species [32], was observed on Cu0.25-Al and these Cuδ+ species were generally considered to be single Cu atoms, which was also confirmed by the absence of Cu-Cu and Cu-O-Cu bonds in EXAFS spectra (Fig. S10) [33]. On the contrary, only another band at 2088 cm−1, attributed to Cu0 nanoparticles [8,32], was observed on Cu x -Al (x = 2.5 to 10). This indicates that Cu species exhibited single atom state on Cu0.25-Al, while only metallic Cu0 nanoparticles were present on Cu x -Al (x = 2.5 to 10). Furthermore, in situ Raman spectroscopy was employed to study chemical state of Cu species of Cu/Al2O3 catalysts. It should be noted that the tiny Cu content of the Cu0.25-Al sample exceeded the detection limit of in situ Raman. On Cu x -Al-oxidized (x = 2.5 to 10), peaks at 273, 321, and 606 cm−1, assigned to phonon vibration of Cu2+ species [34,35] and peaks at 150, and 220 cm−1, assigned to phonon vibration of Cu+ species [35], were observed, indictating that Cu species were in an oxidized state in the unreduced samples (Fig. 2d). However, after reduction, all the peaks attributed to Cu oxides disappeared, indicating that Cu species was in a metallic state in Cu x -Al (x = 2.5 to 10). In summary, the analysis indicated that Cu species existed as single atoms on the Cu0.25-Al sample and as Cu nanoparticles on the Cu x -Al samples (x = 2.5 to 10). H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were conducted to investigate the redox behavior of Cu species on the Cu/Al2O3 catalysts (Fig. S11). The absence of H2 consumption on Cu0.25-Al indicated that the Cu single atoms on this sample were unable to participate in the redox process under the specified conditions. Conversely, a distinct H2 consumption peak (α), attributed to the reduction of small Cu nanoparticles at a lower temperature [36], was observed for the other samples. The intensity of this peak reached its maximum for Cu5-Al, suggesting that the Cu5-Al sample contained a substantial quantity of small Cu nanoparticles with strong redox ability. In the subsequent samples, from Cu7.5-Al to Cu10-Al, the intensity of peak α gradually decreased. Simultaneously, another H2 consumption peak (β), corresponding to the reduction of large Cu nanoparticles at a higher temperature [36,37], began to emerge with increasing intensity, indicating that the number of larger Cu nanoparticles with weaker redox abilities gradually increased in these two samples. Additionally, XRD analysis revealed pronounced Cu phase diffraction peaks in the Cu7.5-Al and Cu10-Al samples, while the particle size statistics further revealed that the Cu7.5-Al and Cu10-Al samples exhibited a proportion of Cu particles of 10 nm and larger. These results further provided compelling evidence that the H2 consumption peak α and β could be attributed to small and large Cu nanoparticles, respectively. N2O titration was utilized to analyze the Cu dispersion and nanoparticle size, allowing for quantification of the concentrations of surface Cu species (CCu) on the Cu/Al2O3 catalysts [8,38]. The first set of H2-TPR data for the completely oxidized samples was used to determine the total Cu content (Fig. S12), while the second set of H2-TPR data for samples after N2O oxidation was utilized to assess the surface Cu content (Fig. S13). The negligible H2 consumption on Cu0.25-Al in the second H2-TPR experiment confirmed that Cu single atoms could not be oxidized by N2O post-reduction. Cu2.5-Al and Cu5-Al samples exhibited high Cu dispersion (DCu) of 38.9 % and 32.8 %, respectively, while the Cu dispersion of Cu7.5-Al and Cu10-Al decreased sharply to 15.4 % and 7.5 %, respectively, indicating that larger Cu nanoparticles reduced Cu dispersion (Table 1 ). Notably, the nanoparticle sizes (dCu) calculated via N2O titration are highly aligned with the particle size statistics obtained from HAADF-STEM analysis. Normalizing the dispersion by the Cu loadings led to the calculation of CCu, which exhibited a similar volcano-shaped trend in line with the H2 production rate as the Cu nanoparticle size increased (Fig. 2e). To further elucidate the relationship between CCu and the H2 production rate, the concentration of surface Cu species (CCu) were calculated for each catalyst (Fig. 2e and Table 1). Remarkably, CCu presented volcano-shaped curves as Cu content increased, with Cu5-Al containing the highest value for CCu (256.25μmol g−1). Interestingly, a linear correlation was discerned between CCu (X) and the H2 production rate (Y), with the relationship given by Y = 0.067X. These findings suggested that the H2 production rate was correlated with the surface Cu sites on Cu nanoparticles. Catalysts with abundant small Cu nanoparticles demonstrated a higher H2 production rate due to the larger amount of surface Cu sites, while catalysts with larger Cu nanoparticle sizes may form fewer surface Cu sites, leading to a lower H2 production rate. To elucidate the reaction mechanism and identify the active sites in methanol steam reforming on Cu/Al2O3 catalysts, in situ DRIFTS-MS experiments were conducted on both Al2O3 and Cu5-Al. On Al2O3 exposed to a CH3OH/H2O/N2 mixture at 323 K (Fig. S14a), abundant methoxy species (2945, 2845, and 2820 cm−1) [11,39] were formed, accompanied by the consumption of hydroxyl groups (Al-OH species, 3800 ∼ 3600 cm−1) [40] due to methanol adsorption (Fig. S15). These indicated that methanol dissociation consumed Al-OH species to form methoxy species (Table S3) [8]. As the temperature was gradually raised to 573 K, the methoxy species gradually disappeared, while new bands corresponding to Al2O3-bound formate (1588 cm−1) appeared [41], along with several bands representing different formate vibrational modes (2905, 1394, and 1373 cm−1) [11,42]. Despite the formation of Al2O3-bound formate, negligible H2 and CO2 production was detected during this procedure (Fig. S14b), indicating the inactivity of Al2O3-bound formate in H2 production. By contrast, on Cu5-Al exposed to a CH3OH/H2O/N2 mixture at 323 K, fewer methoxy species were generated with less consumption of Al-OH species, signifying preferential methanol dissociation on Al2O3 (Fig. S16a). As the temperature increased to 423 K, the generation of Al2O3-bound formate and Cu-Al interfacial formate (1612 cm−1) [43] was observed coupled with the decrease in the number of methoxy species, indicating that methoxy species may be the precursors of formate (Fig. 3 a). As the temperature further rose, the quantity of Cu-Al interfacial formate increased rapidly until 533 K, followed by significant decrease at higher temperatures, while the amount of Al2O3-bound formate exhibited only slight changes (Fig. S16b). Simultaneously, the generation of H2 and CO2 gradually emerged and increased at around 423 K, reaching maximum values at around 513 K, after which they slowly decreased to stable levels (Fig. 3b). The observed alignment of the transformation of Cu-Al interfacial formate with the trends of H2 and CO2 production provided compelling evidence suggesting that the reaction pathway of Cu-Al interfacial formate played a significant role in H2 production. To elucidate the distinct reactivity of formates, step-response experiments were conducted. When Cu5-Al was exposed to a CH3OH/N2 mixture at 523 K (Fig. 3c), Al-OH species consumption and the generation of substantial formate were observed, coupled with the formation of methoxy species and a small amount of formaldehyde (1659 cm−1) [40,41]. This observation indicates the methanol dissociation consumed Al-OH species and its subsequent conversion to formaldehyde and formate. Subsequently, when exposed to N2, the amount of formate exhibited slight changes, indicating its strong binding to the catalyst surface. However, the final introduction of H2O/N2 led to almost complete consumption of reactive Cu-Al interfacial formate within 30 min and replenished Al-OH species, leaving exclusively inert Al2O3-bound formate on the catalyst surface. Notably, Al2O3-bound formate, generated by methoxy and formaldehyde species adsorbed on Al2O3 was gradually consumed, further confirming the continuous involvement of methoxy and formaldehyde species bound to Al sites in the reaction. Concurrently, the concentrations of H2 and CO2 rapidly increased within the first 2 min, peaking around 8 min, and then gradually declined over the next 10 min. This trend aligned with the consumption rate of Cu-Al interfacial formate, while the consumption rate of Al2O3-bound formate exhibited slight change, as determined from the first derivative of the normalized peak area of formate (Figs. 3d and S17g). Additionally, when exposed to methanol at 523 K, only Al2O3-bound formate, accompanied by a substantial amount of formaldehyde (1659, 1633, and 1320 cm−1) [41], was observed on both Al2O3 and Cu0.25-Al, while a lower amount of reactive formate was observed on Cu10-Al (Fig. S17a–c). By the way, the observed water production during the adsorption of methanol on Al2O3 suggested that the H species produced by dehydrogenation of methanol might react with Al-OH to produce water (Fig. S17h). Moreover, the Al2O3-bound formate on both Al2O3 and Cu0.25-Al exhibited poor reactivity toward H2O to produce H2 and CO2 (Fig. S17d, e, and g). These observations further confirmed that the key reaction pathway involved the Cu-Al interfacial formate. In addition, on the Cu10-Al catalyst, the formate showed lower reactivity in producing H2, possibly attributed to inefficiency in H2O activation (Fig. S17f and g). Notably, the weak sensitivity of TOF to Cu nanoparticle size suggested that the H2 production was not exclusively regulated by the interface sites, while the surface Cu species, serving as the primary active sites, determined the H2 production. Interestingly, the consumption of Al2O3-bound formate suggested that Al2O3-bound formate could serve as a supplement to reactive formate, whereby neighboring Al2O3-bound formate may migrate to Cu nanoparticles. This further indicated that formate dehydrogenation, the significant step in H2 production, did not occur exclusively at the Cu-Al interface but rather transferred to the surface Cu species, where it occurred uniformly. Hence, the Cu-Al interface may primarily act as the trigger site to promote the formation of reactive formate. In situ DRIFTS experiments were performed on Al2O3 and Cu/Al2O3 to elucidate the active sites and intermediates involved in water activation. Upon exposure to a H2O/N2 mixture at 473 K, bands at 1650 cm−1 corresponding to the water H-O-H bending [44] mode and negative bands at 3768, 3725, and 3669 cm−1 corresponding to Al-OH species were observed on Al2O3 [40], indicating the dissociation of water may occupy Al-OH sites to form H-bonds, weakening the vibration of Al-OH (Figs. 4 a and S18) [45–47]. In contrast, on Cu5-Al, the adsorption of molecular water and the consumption of Al-OH decreased, while broad bands in the range of 3600–2900 cm−1 were enhanced and a new band at 3735 cm−1 appeared, which indicate that the water dissociation may be facilitated on Cu5-Al to generate some new hydroxyl groups. Notably, upon exposure to a H2O/N2 mixture at 573 K, a similar band at 3735 cm−1 was observed on Cu powder (Fig. S19), which may suggest that the new hydroxyl groups could be associated with Cu-OH species [48,49]. To further verify the generation of Cu-OH species, D2O adsorption experiments were conducted. Upon exposure to a D2O/N2 mixture at 473 K, a weakened vibration of Al-OH was observed on Al2O3, exhibiting varying degrees of redshift compared to that during H2O adsorption (Fig. S20). However, on the Cu5-Al, the weakening of Al-OH vibrations was significantly reduced, while broad OD vibration bands in the range of 2700–2200 cm−1 were greatly enhanced [50]. Furthermore, a new band at 2716 cm−1, with a ratio of 1.38 to the 3735 cm−1 band, was observed. Given that previous studies proposed an isotope shift of 1.36 for Cu-OH and Cu-OD [50–52], these findings confirmed that the 3735 and 2716 cm−1 bands correspond to Cu-OH and Cu-OD species, respectively. In situ Raman was further employed to investigate the redox cycle of Cu species on Cu5-Al during the activation of water. The absence of Cu2+ species (273, 321, and 606 cm−1) and Cu+ species (150, 220 cm−1) [35] confirmed the metallic state of Cu species on Cu5-Al at 298 K (Fig. 4b). After the introduction of water at 323 K, peaks at 184 and 212 cm−1, attributed to the bending vibration of Cu-OH species [53,54] and peaks at 448 and 550 cm−1, assigned to the stretching vibration of Cu-OH species emerged, accompanied by the generation of Cu+ species. This further confirmed that water activation occurs on Cu0 species via oxidizing Cu0 to Cu-OH species, in which the Cu electronic sate was Cu+. As the temperature rose, the number of Cu+-OH species increased, suggesting that the activation of water was enhanced with rising temperature. Notably, despite the temperature rising to 573 K, negligible Cu2+ species were detected, signifying that water could not oxidize Cu0 to Cu2+ throughout the entire range of reaction temperatures. The strong linear correlation between the changes in Cu-OH species (184 cm−1) and Cu+ species (220 cm−1) further indicated that the increase in Cu+ species during water activation was mainly due to the formation of Cu-OH species (Fig. S21). The above results provided compelling evidence that water activation occurs on Cu0 species, oxidizing Cu0 to form Cu+-OH species. Additionally, the amount of Cu+-OH species generated from water activation increased with rising water concentration, suggesting that its production was probably influenced by the partial pressure of water (Fig. S22). This observation indicated that the water activation was likely quasi-equilibrated. By contrast, negligible Cu+-OH species were generated on Cu0.25-Al (Fig. S23), indicating that Cu single atoms could not activate water. Besides, fewer Cu+-OH species were formed on the Cu10-Al catalyst compared to the Cu5-Al catalyst (Fig. S24), indicating that large Cu nanoparticles exhibited a weaker ability to activate water. DFT calculations provided additional insights into the activation of water on the Cu/Al2O3 catalysts. A Cu(111) surface and a single Cu atom on a Al2O3(110) surface (Cu1/Al2O3) were used to represent the Cu nanoparticles and single Cu atom species, respectively. Bader charge analysis indicated that H existed in the form of a proton in adsorbed H2O with a Bader charge of 0.58 e− at the initial state (IS). The dissociation of H2O on Cu(111) would generate Cu-OH and electron-rich H, where the H atom in Cu-H gained 1.10 e− at the final state (FS), with a substantial contribution of electrons (0.60 e−) originating from Cu atoms in Cu-OH (Fig. 4c). This indicated that the Cu species in Cu-OH were present in the Cu+ state, aligning with the Raman results. Further, the electron-rich H may detach more easily from the Cu surface to produce hydrogen [8]. However, H2O dissociation on Cu1/Al2O3 would generate Cu-OH and Al-OH, and the H moiety in H2O only gained 0.32 e− from the O atoms in Al2O3 and H2O at the FS. While the energy barrier for H2O dissociation on Cu1/Al2O3 was lower, the formation of electron-poor H in Al-OH was disadvantageous to the subsequent dehydrogenation (Fig. 4d). In situ DR-UV–vis was employed to probe the dynamics of Cu species on the Cu5-Al catalyst under varying reaction conditions. DR-UV–vis spectra revealed that Cu0 species (560–620 nm) [48,55,56] were present on Cu x -Al (x = 2.5 to 10) samples (Fig. S25). During in situ DR-UV–vis experiments, the oxidized Cu5-Al sample was first reduced in H2/N2 at 573 K for 60 min, followed by subsequent exposure to various gas conditions at different temperatures for 60 min (Fig. 5 ). By the way, the slight changes in the Cu0 species from 573 K to 323 K indicated that temperature had a negligible impact on the background of DR-UV–Vis spectra (Fig. S26). After exposure to a flow of H2O/N2 at 323 K, the number of Cu0 species decreased significantly, suggesting the facile oxidation of Cu0 by water (Fig. 5a). As the temperature further increased to 423 K, the reduced Cu0 species almost completely vanished, further confirming the role of H2O in oxidizing Cu0 species. Besides, the Cu5-Al sample was pretreated in O2/N2 at 473 K, followed by exposure to a flow of CH3OH/N2 (Fig. 5b), this had a minor influence on the Cu0 species. The number of Cu0 species exhibited a remarkable increase at 523 K, while the Cu species were almost entirely reduced at the higher temperature of 573 K. These results revealed the reduction ability of methanol toward Cu species, which was enhanced progressively with rising temperature. Notably, the reduction of Cu species by methanol was more difficult than the oxidation of metallic Cu by water. After exposure to a flow of CH3OH/H2O/N2 at 473 K, the reduced Cu0 species were rapidly oxidized, indicating that the oxidation ability of water outpaced the reduction ability of methanol at temperatures below 523 K (Fig. 5c). In contrast, at 573 K, the Cu species were completely reduced, indicating that the reduction potency of methanol surpassed the oxidation potency of water at higher temperatures. A step-response experiment was further performed on Cu5-Al to investigate the dynamics of Cu species during methanol steam reforming (Fig. 5d). The oxidized Cu5-Al sample was pretreated in H2/N2 and then successively exposed to H2O/N2, CH3OH/N2, H2O/N2, and CH3OH/N2 for 1 h each. At 473 K, Cu0 species were rapidly oxidized in the flow of H2O/N2, while only slight changes occurred after the subsequent gas composition switches. At 523 K, however, once the reaction gas was switched from H2O/N2 to CH3OH/N2, Cu0 species underwent deep oxidation within the first 20 min, probably attributed to the formation of formate [18]. In the succeeding 40 min, part of the Cu species were slowly reduced back to Cu0 species. At 573 K, in the flow of CH3OH/N2, Cu0 species were deeply oxidized within the first 10 min, while almost all Cu species were rapidly reduced to Cu0 species in the subsequent 20 min. Hence, although the reduction induced by methanol predominated over the oxidation of Cu0 species at high temperatures (573 K), the reduction of oxidized Cu species predominated the overall reaction rate at low temperatures. Interestingly, TPR results showed that the H2 reduction temperature of Cu5-Al ranged from 403 K to 473 K, confirming the complete reduction of oxidized Cu species to Cu0 at 573 K, as observed by in situ DR-UV–vis. The lower reduction temperature indicated Cu species might be easily oxidized, consistent with the rapid reoxidation of Cu0 species by H2O. Methanol, with its weaker reduction capability, could not reduce oxidized Cu species at 473 K but achieved partial reduction at higher temperatures. Overall, the reduction behavior observed via in situ DR-UV–vis corresponded to the TPR results. In the process of methanol steam reforming, methanol undergoes continuous dehydrogenation to form methoxy groups and formaldehyde, which subsequently react with water to produce formate, ultimately decomposing into CO2, and H2 is continuously produced by the dehydrogenation [6,10,17,57]. During this process, water activation and active formate formation are critical for H2 production; yet, these issues have not been fully explained in previous studies. In the present work, in situ Raman and DFT results showed that water was mainly activated on Cu0 species, leading to the oxidation of Cu0 to Cu+-OH. Notably, the H moiety generated from H2O dissociation was more likely to transfer to remained Cu0 species, while numerous studies have highlighted the adsorption and dissociation of H2 on Cu0 species [8,58,59]. This suggests that the H moiety produced during the continuous dehydrogenation of methanol may similarly transfer to Cu0 species. Moreover, active formate, as well as the most abundant surface intermediates (MBSI) identified by in situ DRIFTS-MS was Cu-Al interfacial formate, as deduced from the strong correlation between its high reactivity and H2 production tendency. Notably, on the Cu5-Al sample, with strong water activation ability, little formaldehyde accumulated and abundant Cu-Al interfacial formate was formed, while substantial formaldehyde and negligible reactive formate was produced on Al2O3 and Cu0.25-Al samples without water activation ability. These findings indicated that the reactive formate originated from the reaction of formaldehyde and Cu+-OH species. Recent work reported the crucial role of the Cu-Al2O3 interface in MSR, where it generates reactive HCOO-CuAl species [43]. The present work further clarified that the reactive formate originated from the reaction between Cu+-OH and formaldehyde species on Al2O3 and also identified surface Cu species as the active sites for the MSR reaction, with the Cu-Al interface primarily acting as trigger sites to regulate the formation of reactive formate. Based on the above findings, a reaction pathway for methanol steam reforming was proposed (Fig. 6 ). Initially, methanol preferentially adsorbs and dissociates on Al2O3 to form methoxy species (CH3O*), followed by stepwise dehydrogenation to produce formaldehyde (CH2O*). The transfer of hydrogen atoms occurs on the Cu0 nanoparticles, resulting in the production of H2 molecules. Based on the kinetic, thermodynamic, and DFT studies of methanol dehydrogenation and CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, the dissociative adsorption of methanol is likely to be reversible [60–63]. Although the energy barrier for the further dehydrogenation of CH3O* to CH2O* is higher than that of the reverse reaction [10,33,64], the observed rapid kinetics of this step suggests that both the forward and reverse directions are feasible. Simultaneously, water undergoes activation on another Cu0 site, resulting in the generation of Cu+-OH species. During this process, Cu0 sites transfer electrons to the O atoms, leading to the generation of electron-rich hydrogen. The dependence of Cu+-OH species formation on the partial pressure of water, as well as the previous DFT studies reported similar energy barriers for the forward and reverse reactions of water activation, suggesting that the water activation may be quasi-equilibrated [62,65]. Subsequently, an interaction between the formaldehyde and the Cu+-OH species occur, leading to the formation of methylene dioxygen (CH2OO*), which then dehydrogenates to generate reactive formate (HCOO*). The formate then migrated to the surface Cu species for further dehydrogenation. The instability and rapid reaction of the CH2OO* intermediate, along with the slightly higher energy barrier for the reverse reaction, suggest limited reversibility for this process [10,66]. Finally, the uniform dehydrogenation of formate on the surface Cu species produced H2 and CO2, thus completing the redox cycle between Cu0 and Cu+. Notably, the dehydrogenation of HCOO* proceeded slowly with a high energy barrier [10,33], indicating that this step may be both the rate-determining step and partially irreversible. The hypothesized active sites, dynamically formed, comprise dynamic Cu0/+ sites coupled with Cu0 sites. The formation of Cu+ arises from the oxidation of Cu0 by water, likely involving electron transfer from Cu0 to the adsorbed water. Concurrently, the reduction of Cu+ by methanol potentially involves electron transfer from formate to Cu+ during dehydrogenation. Notably, the rate-determining step (RDS) in the MSR reaction has garnered significant attention among researchers. While some studies suggest that the rate-determining step is the dehydrogenation of CH3O* [43,61], others have demonstrated through DFT calculations that the dissociation energy barrier of H2O is higher than that of CH3O* dehydrogenation [10]. Furthermore, certain researchers have proposed that the rate-determining step transitions to HCOO* dehydrogenation under specific catalysts [8]. In present work, the dehydrogenation of CH3O* was not considered to be the rate-determining step of MSR, since the dehydrogenation of CH3O* on inactive Al2O3 occurred rapidly, while the rapid oxidation of Cu0 species by water also indicated that the dissociation of water was not the rate-determining step. While the size of Cu nanoparticles could affect its ability of water activation, the rapid process of water activation would not significantly limit the overall H2 production rate. Instead, the gradually increasing reduction of Cu+ at low temperature was correlated with the MSR activity, suggesting that at lower temperatures, the dehydrogenation of formate, which led to the reduction of Cu+, may be the rate-determining step of methanol steam reforming on Cu/Al2O3 catalysts. In contrast to previous studies that primarily focused on the initial content of Cu0 and Cu+ species in the catalyst [8,13,54,67], and notwithstanding recent demonstrations of MSR activity enhancements through Cu0-Cu+ interfacial sites [8], the present work has innovatively monitored the dynamic changes of Cu species during the reaction, revealing the presence of a dynamic Cu0/+-Cu0 active site in MSR. Considering the potential morphological changes of copper catalysts during specific processes [68], the dynamic observation of copper morphology changes in MSR reaction emerges as a crucial task for future research. Furthermore, the dependence of the H2 production rate on CCu indicates that the active sites in methanol steam reforming are surface Cu species, which would be regulated by the size of Cu nanoparticles. Hence, small Cu nanoparticles (like ∼ 3 nm in the Cu5Al sample) will optimize the number of active sites, while Cu single atoms cannot activate water, and large Cu nanoparticles suffer from a deficiency of surface Cu sites. Interestingly, previous studies have shown that the activity of Cu-based catalysts tended to initially increase and then decrease with extended test duration [69,70]. The initial increase in activity was often termed self-activation [71,72], while the subsequent decrease was termed deactivation [73,74]. Combined with the above results, the self-activation process possibly stems from the gradual enlargement of Cu nanoparticles to the optimal particle size. However, further enlargement may lead to sintering and subsequent deactivation [75]. 4 Conclusions This study elucidates a dynamic active sites mechanism for methanol steam reforming over Cu/Al2O3 catalysts, wherein a dynamic Cu0/+ site and an adjacent Cu0 site are proposed as the active sites. Water is activated on Cu0 site, oxidizing it to Cu+-OH species. These Cu+-OH species subsequently promote the formation of reactive formate that produce H2 and CO2 upon dehydrogenation, while reducing Cu+ back to Cu0. The small size Cu nanoparticles provide abundant active surface Cu sites, enhancing catalytic performance. Compared to the facile activation of water, the dehydrogenation of formate may be the rate-determining step of the reaction at lower temperatures. The Cu0/+-Cu0 sites represent a departure from previous static models, showcasing the dynamic nature of active Cu sites during methanol steam reforming. This work provides new insights into the dynamics of active sites on copper catalysts during methanol steam reforming, providing guidance for high-efficiency catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Methanol steam reforming (MSR) is essential for in-situ hydrogen production, providing a clean fuel alternative for sustainable energy applications. Copper catalysts are widely applied in MSR, yet the nature of active sites and reaction pathway involved remain some debates. Herein, we reveal the crucial role of water activation and dynamic active sites on Cu/Al2O3 catalysts during the MSR reaction. Specifically, methanol was preferentially adsorbed on Al2O3 and underwent stepwise dehydrogenation to formaldehyde, while water was activated on metallic Cu, oxidizing Cu0 to form Cu+-OH species, accompanied by hydrogen migration to another Cu0 site. The Cu+-OH species further reacted with formaldehyde to generate highly reactive formate, whose dehydrogenation produced CO2. Concurrently, the Cu+ was reduced back to the Cu0 state, and H2 was continuously produced by dehydrogenation. Compared to the facile oxidation of Cu0 by water, the slow reduction of Cu+ induced by the dehydrogenation of formate predominated the overall reaction rate at low temperatures. These findings provide new insights into a dynamic Cu0/+-Cu0 site mechanism on copper catalysts in methanol steam reforming, beneficial for the design of efficient MSR catalysts.
